content.title: ANCA-Associated Vasculitis - Renal Manifestations
content.summary: ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) represents a group of small-vessel vasculitides (GPA, MPA, EGPA) that commonly cause pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis. Renal involvement is characterized by rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), requiring urgent diagnosis and immunosuppressive therapy to preserve kidney function.
key_points: Three AAV types: GPA (c-ANCA/PR3), MPA (p-ANCA/MPO), EGPA (p-ANCA with eosinophilia)
Pauci-immune GN: Crescentic GN with absent/minimal immune deposits on IF
RPGN presentation: AKI, hematuria, proteinuria, RBC casts over days to weeks
Pulmonary-renal syndrome: Concurrent diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) is emergency
Treatment: Rituximab or cyclophosphamide + glucocorticoids for induction
Plasmapheresis for severe renal disease (creatinine >5.7) or DAH
content.statement: ANCA-associated vasculitis causes pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis manifesting as rapidly progressive renal failure, requiring prompt recognition and aggressive immunosuppression to prevent irreversible kidney damage.

explanation.intuition: Think of ANCA as 'friendly fire' - antibodies that mistakenly target neutrophils, causing them to attack small blood vessels including glomerular capillaries. The resulting inflammation destroys the glomerulus rapidly, forming crescents (like the moon shape) of proliferating cells that obliterate the filtering space.
explanation.key_insight: The 'pauci-immune' nature is key: unlike other glomerulonephritides with prominent immune deposits, AAV shows minimal deposits because the damage is from activated neutrophils rather than immune complex deposition. ANCA testing plus biopsy showing crescentic GN with absent IF staining clinches the diagnosis.
explanation.technical_details: PR3-ANCA (c-ANCA pattern) is associated with GPA; MPO-ANCA (p-ANCA pattern) with MPA and EGPA. ANCA activate primed neutrophils to release toxic contents and adhere to endothelium. Biopsy shows segmental fibrinoid necrosis, cellular/fibrocellular crescents, and negative or 'pauci' (<2+) immunofluorescence.

definitions_glossary.ANCA: Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies targeting neutrophil granule proteins
definitions_glossary.GPA: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener's); upper/lower respiratory + renal
definitions_glossary.MPA: Microscopic polyangiitis; renal-dominant or pulmonary-renal without granulomas
definitions_glossary.EGPA: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss); asthma + eosinophilia
definitions_glossary.pauci_immune: Absence or paucity of immunoglobulin/complement on immunofluorescence
definitions_glossary.crescentic_GN: Glomerulonephritis with crescent formation in >50% of glomeruli on biopsy
definitions_glossary.RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis; renal failure over days to weeks
definitions_glossary.PR3_ANCA: Proteinase 3 antibodies; cytoplasmic (c-ANCA) pattern; associated with GPA
definitions_glossary.DAH: Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage; life-threatening pulmonary complication
definitions_glossary.BVAS: Birmingham Vasculitis Activity Score; standardized disease activity measure

pathophysiology.mechanism: ANCA bind to surface-expressed PR3 or MPO on primed neutrophils, causing activation, endothelial adhesion, and release of toxic granule contents leading to small vessel necrosis

clinical_presentation: Rapidly progressive AKI (creatinine doubling over weeks)
Active urine sediment: dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts
Constitutional symptoms: fever, weight loss, fatigue
laboratory_findings: Positive ANCA (PR3 or MPO) by ELISA

induction_therapy.mild_moderate: Rituximab 375mg/mÂ² weekly x 4 OR cyclophosphamide + high-dose glucocorticoids
induction_therapy.severe: Rituximab or cyclophosphamide + plasmapheresis if creatinine >5.7 mg/dL or DAH
induction_therapy.glucocorticoids: Pulse methylprednisolone 500-1000mg x 3 days, then oral prednisone taper

definition.@value: Renal manifestation of ANCA-associated small vessel vasculitis, characterized by pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive renal failure

scopeNote.@value: Focuses on renal involvement in GPA, MPA, and EGPA with diagnosis and treatment

learning_objectives: Differentiate GPA, MPA, and EGPA by clinical and serologic features
Recognize RPGN presentation requiring urgent biopsy
Select appropriate induction and maintenance therapy
Identify indications for plasmapheresis in AAV
clinical_pearls: ANCA-negative AAV exists (~10%) - biopsy is still diagnostic
Drug-induced ANCA (PTU, hydralazine) is usually MPO-ANCA positive
Rituximab non-inferior to cyclophosphamide for induction (RAVE trial)
Pulmonary-renal syndrome = emergency; start treatment before biopsy
Recovery from dialysis-dependence possible with aggressive treatment
common_misconceptions: All AAV is ANCA-positive - 10% are ANCA-negative
Dialysis-dependent = irreversible - recovery possible with treatment
PR3 always means GPA - MPO can occur in GPA too
